timeline.message:
front-end: Use React Testing Library for SearchPagination.test.tsx

This is mainly a stepping stone to assist with SearchPage.test.tsx, but I needed to be able to interact properly with the search pagination controls. Hence, this also includes the big update in SearchPaginationTestHelper.ts.
front-end: Improve accessibility and testability of SearchOrderSelect

front-end: Fix issue with DateRangeSelector

I'm concerned though, as I thought when @mrblippy did this it did not work with ESLint errors. Everything seems happy here.
front-end: Refactor SearchPage.test.tsx to only use React Testing Library

front-end: Minimise use of fireEvent.change()

To ensure that tests are closer to how the components are used by users in the browser.

timeline.bodyText: To improve accessibility, but also testability. Follows MUI recommendations - as far as using InputLabel etc. However I put the display: none so as to ensure it looked no different to before.
timeline.author: edalex-ian

replies.bodyText: I actually feel  without display: none the UI looks better for me. This is because when the default sorting has not been configured, it is undefined. As a result, this control shows nothing. But if a lable is showed there, it helps me know this control is about sorting

replies.bodyText:
From what I saw, it looks like this could possibly work with <Autocomplete>s. But for the one I was testing it didn't have an ID but did have a rather specific text label ('Collections') so I didn't end up using selectOption. But the code I did use was basically the same - just started with a getByText or getByLabel on the rendered component.
(The other issue I had trying to check with <Autocomplete>, is when attempting to inspect the DOM to check, the autocomplete would close the drop down list and so I couldn't see for sure.)

timeline.bodyText: Ah this is what you described yesterday.  userEvent.click consists of a few events such as keydown whereas fireEvent does not.  MUI Select might listens to keydown  rather than 'click'.

replies.bodyText: That's correct. I wasted a good number of hours until I discovered MUI selects register onMouseDown not onClick. userEvent allows you to not worry about this - just like a user wouldn't worry about it.
